ProgramName: Master of Science in Accounting
EnglishScore: All applicants to the School of Graduate Studies whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT - 79; TOEFL Essentials - 8.5; International English Language Testing System (IELTS) - 6.0; Pearson Test of English (PTE) - 53; Duolingo - 110; Successful completion of the English as a Second Language (ESL) program - Level 112 certificate of completion from an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: To be considered for admission to the Master of Science in Accounting (M.S.A.) program, applicants must meet the general requirements for admission to graduate studies at UMKC and meet the following program requirements: Completion of a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution, GMAT/GRE is currently optional, Cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher, Prerequisite course completion. Required documents for all applicants: Completed online application, Official transcripts from all previously attended institutions, Official GMAT or GRE score report (if applicable), Resume, Personal statement. International students have additional requirements.
Department: Henry W. Bloch School of Management
Fees: Missouri Resident: $19,986 (total for 30 credits); Non-Resident: $37,965 (total for 30 credits)
Description: The Master of Science in Accounting (MSA) program at the Bloch School of Management is designed for students with an undergraduate degree in accounting who want to complete the 150-hour requirement for CPA licensure and gain more specialized knowledge in specific areas of accounting. Our MSA program is for students who have a bachelor’s degree in accounting (or the equivalent coursework).
Accredidation: The Bloch School holds dual accreditation from the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) for both our business and accounting programs.

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Acting and Directing
EnglishScore: Applicants who are not native speakers of English must demonstrate English proficiency. Acceptable forms of documentation include official scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Pearson Test of English (PTE) or Duolingo.
Description: The MFA in Acting and Directing is a three-year, 60-credit hour terminal degree program. In conjunction with our partner, the Kansas City Repertory Theatre (an Equity LORT B theatre), the UMKC Theatre MFA program is dedicated to the training of the total theatre artist. The program provides an environment in which a select company of gifted students receive conservatory training in conjunction with a professional theatre. The successful completion of three years of training will culminate in the Master of Fine Arts degree. This program is designed to develop highly skilled actors and directors who can translate their training into successful careers in the professional theatre. This is primarily accomplished through intensive studio work, a rigorous production schedule, and the unique opportunity to work alongside the professionals at the Kansas City Repertory Theatre.
Accredidation: UMKC Theatre is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Theatre (NAST). UMKC's Graduate Acting Program is a member of the University/Resident Theatre Association (U/RTA).
AverageScholarshipAmount: $14,000 stipend per academic year + full tuition waiver
ScholarshipAmount: $14,000 stipend per academic year + full tuition waiver
ScholarshipType: Tuition waiver and graduate teaching assistantship

ProgramName: Master of Science in Anesthesia
Description: The Master of Science in Anesthesia Program at the University of Missouri-Kansas City School of Medicine is a 28-month graduate program that prepares students for a career as a Certified Anesthesiologist Assistant (CAA). The UMKC MSA Program is fully accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs (CAAHEP). Certified Anesthesiologist Assistants are highly skilled health professionals who work under the direction of licensed anesthesiologists to implement anesthesia care plans. CAAs work exclusively within the anesthesia care team environment as described by the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA). All CAAs must be graduates of a master's level CAAHEP accredited program, and must pass a certifying examination administered by the National Commission for Certification of Anesthesiologist Assistants (NCCAA). The UMKC MSA Program is administered within the School of Medicine, and the clinical instruction is provided by the Department of Anesthesiology. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in the basic and clinical sciences relevant to the practice of anesthesiology, and emphasizes the development of the cognitive, psychomotor, and affective skills necessary for the delivery of safe, effective, and compassionate anesthetic care.
Accredidation: The UMKC MSA Program is fully accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs (CAAHEP).

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Art History
EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must meet UMKC's English language proficiency requirements. Minimum scores for graduate students are: Internet-based TOEFL (iBT) or TOEFL iBT Home Edition score of 80 or higher, Paper-based TOEFL (pBT) score of 550 or higher, IELTS or IELTS Indicator score of 6.0 or higher, Pearson Test of English (PTE) score of 53 or higher, Duolingo English Test score of 105 or higher, or successful completion of the English Language Services (ELS) Level 112.
Requirements: Admission to the Master of Arts Program in Art History is based on an evaluation of the following materials: A completed UMKC Graduate Application; Official transcripts of all previous college and university work; A minimum grade-point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale in all previous college and university work, and a 3.2 in all art history coursework; Three letters of recommendation from former instructors or other qualified persons who can assess the applicant’s capacity for graduate study; A curriculum vitae (CV); A one-to-two-page statement of intent describing the applicant’s past academic training, interests in art history, and professional goals; A writing sample (10-20 pages) that demonstrates the applicant’s research and writing abilities; International students must also submit TOEFL scores of at least 80 (Internet-based) or IELTS scores of 6.0.
Description: The Master of Arts in Art History program offers a comprehensive curriculum that encompasses a wide variety of historical periods and diverse cultural traditions. The program provides two years of specialized art historical study and is designed for students who desire a strong background in art history, research methodology, and critical theory. Students gain a solid foundation in the history of art and acquire research, writing and critical thinking skills that can be applied to many different professional opportunities. The program prepares graduates for doctoral studies and for careers as curators in museums, galleries, and corporate collections, as well as positions in arts administration, publishing, historic preservation, and education.
ScholarshipAmount: stipend of about $14,000 for the academic year

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Bioinformatics
EnglishScore: International students must meet the English proficiency requirements of the School of Graduate Studies. Accepted tests include TOEFL with a minimum score of 79 (internet-based) or 550 (paper-based), IELTS with a minimum overall score of 6.0, PTE Academic with a minimum score of 53, or Duolingo with a minimum score of 105. Exemptions are available for students who have graduated from institutions in countries where English is the native language.
Requirements: Applicants must meet all requirements of the School of Graduate Studies. Bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. Must have completed two semesters of biology, two semesters of general chemistry, and at least one semester of organic chemistry. A cumulative GPA of at least 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale) in the bachelor's degree-conferring institution. Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. UMKC’s English proficiency requirements for graduate students can be found here. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions. Three letters of recommendation. These should be from professionals or academics who can attest to your academic potential and character. A personal statement addressing your interest in bioinformatics, your career goals, and why you believe you are a good fit for our program. A current resume or curriculum vitae (CV). GRE scores are optional. If you choose to submit them, they will be considered as part of a holistic review of your application.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $8,500 for the Chancellor's Non-Resident Award; $1,000 for the School of Graduate Studies Fellowship.

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Biology
EnglishScore: International applicants must demonstrate English language proficiency to be considered for admission to UMKC. Applicants must submit official scores from one of the following exams, taken within the last two years: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT - minimum score 79, International English Language Testing System (IELTS) - minimum score 6.0, Pearson Test of English (PTE) - minimum score 53, Duolingo English Test - minimum score 105.
Description: The Master of Arts in Biology is designed to provide students with a broad background in biology, allowing them to pursue a variety of career objectives. Students may use the degree as a terminal degree, a preparatory step for further professional training (e.g., medicine, dentistry), or a stepping stone for Ph.D. study. The M.A. in biology is offered under two options: thesis and non-thesis. The thesis option involves a significant research experience and provides a better preparation for Ph.D. study. Both thesis and non-thesis options allow coursework to be taken from within the School of Science and Engineering and from the professional schools of Medicine, Dentistry, and Pharmacy.

ProgramName: Master of Business Administration in Business Administration
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following options prior to admission.
Requirements: A completed online application. Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. A current resume. A one-page personal statement outlining your professional goals. Official GMAT or GRE score reports.
Department: Henry W. Bloch School of Management
Concentration: Business Analytics, Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Finance, Leading and Managing People, Marketing, Supply Chain Management, General Management
Description: The UMKC Bloch School Professional Master of Business Administration (PMBA) is Kansas City's premier part-time MBA program, designed to help working professionals advance their careers. It's the only AACSB-accredited program in the region that allows students to choose from seven focus areas and earn a graduate certificate while completing their MBA at no extra cost. In just two years, you can earn your degree and elevate your future. A convenient, flexible schedule helps you balance school, work and life. Classes are offered one night a week in a hybrid format, allowing for both online and in-person instruction.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $2,000

ProgramName: Master of Science in Cell and Molecular Biology
EnglishScore: All applicants to the School of Graduate Studies whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following: a minimum TOEFL (iBT) score of 80, a minimum IELTS score of 6.0, a minimum PTE score of 53, a minimum Duolingo score of 110, or successful completion of ELS level 112 with a grade of B or better.
Requirements: Minimum GPA of 3.0. Required Application Materials: Unofficial transcripts from all previously attended institutions, Statement of purpose, Three letters of recommendation, Resume or curriculum vitae, Official GRE scores. The GRE may be waived for applicants with a 3.2 GPA or higher, but is otherwise required for admission. UMKC's institutional code is 6872. Official TOEFL, IELTS, PTE or Duolingo scores (for international students).
Description: The Master of Science program in Cell and Molecular Biology offers students the opportunity to choose between two emphases: a research-based thesis emphasis, or a non-thesis coursework-based emphasis. The thesis option provides graduate students with extensive laboratory training that prepares them for future work in an academic or industrial research setting, or for continuing on to Ph.D. or professional programs. The non-thesis option enables students to strengthen their science backgrounds through coursework for various reasons, including to prepare for professional school or for career advancement. All students will work with a faculty advisor in the School of Science and Engineering to tailor their educational program to suit their career interests.
ScholarshipType: Teaching assistantships, research assistantships, graduate fellowships

ProgramName: Master of Science in Chemistry (non-thesis)
EnglishScore: For international applicants, a TOEFL score of 550 (paper-based) or 213 (computer-based) or 79 (Internet-based); or an IELTS score of 6.0.
Fees: Resident: ~$16,611; Non-Resident: ~$38,412. This is an estimated total program tuition based on 30 credit hours and the 2023-2024 per-credit rate.
Description: The Master of Science in Chemistry provides advanced training in specialized fields of chemistry and is designed to prepare students for professional employment in chemistry, for teaching chemistry at the secondary or community college level or for admission to a Ph.D. program in chemistry or a related discipline.
CostPerCredit: Resident: $553.70/credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,280.40/credit hour (for Master's programs in the School of Science and Engineering, as of 2023-2024 rates).
CollegeApplicationFee: Resident: ~$16,611; Non-Resident: ~$38,412. This is an estimated total program tuition based on 30 credit hours and the 2023-2024 per-credit rate.
MinimumGreScore: A combined verbal and quantitative score of 300 is desired
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by award. For example, the Arthur Mag Graduate Fellowship provides a $12,500 stipend and the UMKC Trustees' Scholar Award is for $1,000.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Chemistry (thesis)
EnglishScore: All applicants to UMKC whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency before admission. This requirement can be satisfied by submitting official scores for one of the following exams: a score of 79 or higher on the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT, a score of 550 or higher on the TOEFL pBT, a score of 6.0 or higher on the International English Language Testing System (IELTS), a score of 53 or higher on the Pearson Test of English (PTE), a score of 120 or higher on the Duolingo English Test, or successful completion of Level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: For admission to the M.S. program, a student must have completed the equivalent of an undergraduate major in chemistry at a college or university of recognized standing. This major must have included a year of physical chemistry based on calculus. The undergraduate grade-point average should be at least 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale). Exceptions can be made on the recommendation of the chemistry graduate committee. A student with minor deficiencies in undergraduate training may be admitted, but the deficiencies must be removed without graduate credit.
Description: The Department of Chemistry offers graduate work leading to the Master of Science (M.S.) and Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) degrees in chemistry. Major areas of study are analytical, inorganic, organic and physical chemistry. The M.S. program is offered with either a thesis or non-thesis option, and is designed for students seeking positions in industrial research and/or development, government laboratories, and teaching. A thesis M.S. degree is strongly recommended for students who plan to enter a Ph.D. program. The thesis-based M.S. degree requires the satisfactory completion of 30 credit hours. An oral defense of a written thesis describing an original research project is required.
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $559.50 per credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,240.80 per credit hour (2023-2024 rates)
ScholarshipAmount: The nine-month stipend for a Graduate Teaching Assistant (GTA) is $17,000, and educational fees are typically waived.
ScholarshipType: Graduate Teaching Assistantships (GTAs), Graduate Research Assistantships (GRAs)

ProgramName: Master of Science in Civil Engineering
Requirements:
Applicants for admission to the M.S. degree program in civil engineering must have a B.S. degree in civil engineering from an ABET-accredited program with a GPA of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale), or its equivalent.

Applicants holding an undergraduate degree in a discipline other than civil engineering may be admitted to provisional status and required to complete a series of undergraduate articulation courses with a GPA of 3.0 or better before they are granted full admission status. Articulation courses for individual students will be determined by the Civil Engineering Graduate Admission Committee.

GRE general test requirement is waived for all applicants. However, applicants who do not have a B.S. degree from an ABET-accredited institution are strongly encouraged to submit GRE scores.

The minimum acceptable TOEFL score for applicants whose native language is not English is 550 (paper-based) or 213 (computer-based) or 79 (Internet-based). The minimum acceptable IELTS score is an overall band score of 6.0. The minimum acceptable PTE-A score is an overall score of 53. The minimum acceptable Duolingo score is an overall score of 115.
Description: The Master of Science in Civil Engineering (MSCE) program provides an opportunity for students to prepare for leadership roles in the civil engineering profession. This program is for students with an engineering baccalaureate degree who desire advanced knowledge in civil engineering. The program will equip students with advanced skills in planning, design, analysis, and management of civil engineering systems. Students learn to address the challenges of sustainable infrastructure and the environment, such as those related to water, transportation, housing, and energy systems. The MSCE program at UMKC offers two emphasis areas: Structural Engineering and Transportation Engineering. The program of study may be tailored to emphasize one of the two areas, or a more broad-based plan of study may be developed. The MSCE degree program also offers a thesis option and a non-thesis coursework-only option for both emphasis areas. The thesis option involves in-depth research with a faculty member on a topic of mutual interest. The non-thesis option requires coursework only and culminates in a final comprehensive exam. The MSCE program is available to students on campus or online through the UMKC Online program.
ScholarshipAmount: $1,000 to $8,500 per year

ProgramName: Master of Science in Computer Science
EnglishScore: If your native language is not English, you will need to demonstrate English proficiency by submitting one of the following: TOEFL (79 iBT or 550 pBT), IELTS (6.0 overall band score), PTE (53), Duolingo (110), or ELS (Level 112 with a 2.5 GPA).
Requirements: Online application; Official transcripts; GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale; GRE is no longer required for admission; Resume (optional); Personal statement or statement of purpose (optional); Letters of recommendation (optional); International applicants must also submit English proficiency test scores.
Concentration: ['Networking and Telecommunications', 'Software Engineering', 'Bioinformatics', 'Data Science', 'General Computer Science']
Description: The Master of Science in Computer Science (M.S.C.S.) degree program provides a student with a graduate-level education that is highly respected and a foundation for a successful career. Our program blends a solid core of theoretical and practical computer science with opportunities for focused study in several emphasis areas. We emphasize practical application through lab-based courses and a significant capstone experience. The capstone experience can be met by completing a master's thesis or graduate project. Our program is designed to meet the needs of both the full-time student and the working professional. Courses are held in the late afternoon and evening to accommodate students with daytime employment. UMKC's location in a major metropolitan area provides students many opportunities for employment. Our faculty are experts who work closely with students to provide an outstanding educational experience. Students have access to state-of-the-art computing facilities including Windows and Unix labs. A dedicated server is available for research activities.

ProgramName: Master of Music in Conducting
EnglishScore: International students must submit a TOEFL, IELTS, PTE or Duolingo score. Minimum scores for graduate degree programs are: TOEFL iBT 79, TOEFL PBT 550, IELTS 6.0, PTE 53, or Duolingo 110. Completion of ELS Level 112 with a minimum GPA of 2.5 is also accepted.
Requirements: Minimum GPA: 3.0. A bachelor's degree in music from a regionally accredited institution is required. Applicants must submit a resume/CV, personal statement, three letters of recommendation, and a scholarly paper on a musical topic. Prescreening recordings are also required. An on-campus audition is required if invited.
Concentration: Choral Conducting emphasis, Instrumental Conducting emphasis
Description: The Master of Music in conducting offers advanced, specialized training in conducting to those who have already attained a high level of proficiency as conductors. This degree will train conductors in the areas of ensemble technique, score study and repertoire. The program is specifically designed to prepare students for entrance into doctoral studies or to work as a professional conductor.
Accredidation: The UMKC Conservatory is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM).

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Counseling
EnglishScore: All applicants to UMKC whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Minimum scores accepted are: TOEFL iBT of 79, TOEFL PBT of 550, IELTS of 6.0, PTE of 53, or Duolingo of 110. Successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112 also meets the requirement.
Department: School of Education, Social Work and Psychological Sciences
Concentration: Mental Health Counseling, Marriage, Couple and Family Counseling
Description: The Master of Arts (M.A.) in Counseling program at the University of Missouri-Kansas City (UMKC) prepares graduate students to become professional counselors. Our program is nationally accredited by the Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP). We train students to work with a wide range of mental health issues in a variety of settings. Students who successfully complete our program are eligible for professional licensure in Missouri and Kansas. The M.A. in Counseling degree is a 60-credit hour program that provides the knowledge and skills necessary for the practice of professional counseling. Our program offers two emphasis areas: Mental Health Counseling and Marriage, Couple and Family Counseling.
Accredidation: Our program is nationally accredited by the Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP).

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts
EnglishScore: International applicants must meet the English proficiency requirements set by the School of Graduate Studies. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT score of 79, IELTS overall score of 6.0, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic score of 53, or Duolingo English Test score of 110. Completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112 is also accepted.
Requirements:
To be considered for admission, applicants must submit the following materials:

- An online UMKC application for admission
- A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution
- Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended
- Three letters of recommendation
- A statement of purpose (should address your background in creative writing and your goals for the MFA program)
- A writing sample (should consist of 20-30 pages of fiction or nonfiction, or 10-15 pages of poetry. It should represent your best work and demonstrate your readiness for graduate study in creative writing.)
- A CV or résumé
Description: The Master of Fine Arts program in creative writing and media arts at the University of Missouri-Kansas City offers advanced training in the literary arts to a diverse community of writers in fiction, nonfiction, poetry and cross-genre work. Our degree provides students with the time, guidance, and community necessary to hone their craft. We are a three-year, 45-credit-hour program that values both literary and media arts, and we offer a course of study that stresses the interconnectedness of writing and publishing, creative practice and professional development. Our flexible and innovative curriculum combines a focus on writing workshops with a wide array of craft seminars, literature courses, and professional opportunities, allowing students to tailor their graduate studies to their own aesthetic and professional goals. Our program’s award-winning faculty is composed of dedicated teachers and mentors who publish widely and work at the forefront of their fields. Small class sizes of 15 or fewer students promote a strong sense of community and foster supportive and enduring relationships among students and faculty.
ScholarshipAmount: Graduate Teaching Assistantships include a minimum stipend of $10,000 per academic year and a full tuition waiver.
ScholarshipType: Graduate Teaching Assistantships, Program-specific scholarships and awards

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts, Concentration in Playwriting
EnglishScore: All applicants who are not citizens of a TOEFL-exempt country must submit official scores for one of the following exams: TOEFL iBT (minimum score of 80), TOEFL Essentials (minimum score of 8.5), IELTS (minimum score of 6.0), PTE (minimum score of 53), or Duolingo English Test (minimum score of 110).
Description: The Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts at UMKC is a three-year, 45-hour terminal degree program that prepares students for careers as professional writers, editors, teachers of creative writing, and for other related positions in the literary arts. With a student to faculty ratio of about 3 to 1, our MFA program is small, selective, and offers a high degree of individual attention to each student. Our students develop a major portfolio of creative work in a chosen genre (Fiction, Poetry, Creative Nonfiction, or Playwriting), receive practical training in the teaching of creative writing, and gain editorial experience working with one of our three national literary journals: New Letters, a quarterly of writing and art; BkMk Press, a publisher of full-length books of poetry, fiction and creative nonfiction; and Number One, a journal for undergraduate creative writing and art. Our curriculum supports both traditional and experimental forms of writing and encourages cross-genre study. MFA students may take up to 6 hours of coursework from the other genres or from other departments at UMKC. The program offers graduate teaching assistantships and other forms of financial aid on a competitive basis. For full funding consideration, students should submit their applications by January 15.
CostPerCredit: $560.70/credit hour for residents, $1,263.90/credit hour for non-residents

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts, Concentration in Poetry
EnglishScore: All applicants to UMKC whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT total score of 79, IELTS Academic overall band score of 6.0, PTE Academic overall score of 53, or Duolingo English Test overall score of 105.
Description: The Master of Fine Arts (MFA) in Creative Writing & Media Arts is a three-year, 45-credit-hour program that prepares students for careers as writers, editors, teachers, and professionals in the arts and media. Students choose a primary emphasis in fiction, poetry, or creative nonfiction, and they are encouraged to work in other genres and media. Our award-winning faculty consists of a diverse group of authors who have published over sixty books. Students gain teaching experience, work as editors on our nationally-distributed literary journals, and receive mentorship in their creative and professional lives. We are committed to fostering an inclusive and supportive community for all of our students.
ScholarshipAmount: Full tuition waiver and a stipend of at least $15,000/year

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts, Concentration in Screenwriting
EnglishScore: For applicants whose native language is not English, proficiency must be demonstrated with one of the following minimum scores: TOEFL iBT of 79, IELTS of 6.0, PTE of 53, or Duolingo English Test of 105. Successful completion of ELS Language Centers' English for Academic Purposes Level 112 is also accepted.
Requirements: A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. Minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for undergraduate coursework. A statement of purpose (1-2 pages) describing the applicant’s interest in the UMKC M.F.A. program, their creative background, and their goals. A writing sample demonstrating creative potential in screenwriting: one feature-length screenplay, one one-hour teleplay, or two half-hour teleplays. The sample must be formatted in standard industry format. A résumé of relevant experience (professional and academic). Three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with the applicant’s academic and/or creative work.
Description: The Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts is a three-year, 45-credit-hour program that provides advanced, integrated training in the writing of fiction, poetry and screenplays, as well as in the craft of literary editing and publishing through courses taught by our distinguished faculty. In our MFA program, you can choose one of three emphasis areas: Fiction, Poetry, Screenwriting. Our program offers students hands-on training in literary editing and publishing through our nationally distributed literary journals, BKMK Press and Number One. We offer competitive graduate teaching assistantships that provide full tuition waivers, a yearly stipend and valuable teaching experience. Our students have the opportunity to serve as editorial assistants for our literary journals, to teach creative writing in the community through our outreach programs and to participate in a vibrant reading series that brings nationally recognized writers to campus.
ScholarshipPercentage: 50% - 100% of the non-resident portion of tuition

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts, Concentration in Creative Nonfiction
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. This can be done by holding a degree from a U.S. regionally accredited institution or a recognized university in a country where English is the official language, or by submitting official minimum test scores: TOEFL iBT (80), IELTS (6.0), PTE (53), or Duolingo (110).
Requirements:
Applicants to the M.F.A. program in creative writing must have:
1. An on-line application through the UMKC Office of Admissions.
2. A bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university.
3. An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale.
4. A statement of purpose of approximately 500 words describing the applicant's background and interest in graduate study in creative writing.
5. A writing sample in the genre to which they are applying (20-25 pages of prose or 10-15 pages of poetry). The writing sample for Media Arts applicants may consist of a single substantial work or a portfolio of smaller works that, in total, amounts to one of the following: 10-15 pages of scriptwriting for any medium; OR a completed media work of up to 10 minutes in length, for which the applicant served as primary creator (writer, director, etc.); OR a portfolio of media work of various lengths totaling up to 15 minutes.
6. Three letters of recommendation addressing the applicant's potential for success in a graduate creative writing program.
7. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
Description: UMKC’s Master of Fine Arts program is nationally ranked and offers tracks in fiction, poetry, and creative nonfiction. It is a three-year, 42-hour course of study that offers a firm grounding in the traditions of the genre while also encouraging experimentation. Our classes are small, typically around 12 students, which allows for an intimate and supportive writing community. We are a fully funded program, and all students admitted to the program receive full tuition waivers, a yearly stipend, and the opportunity to teach. Many of our students are also offered opportunities to work for UMKC’s nationally-recognized literary journals, BkMk Press and New Letters.
ScholarshipAmount: about $13,500 (stipend for Graduate Teaching Assistants)
ScholarshipPercentage: Up to 100% (full tuition remission for Graduate Teaching Assistants)

ProgramName: Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing and Media Arts, Concentration in Fiction
EnglishScore: All applicants to UMKC whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. UMKC accepts the following tests: TOEFL iBT (minimum 79), IELTS (minimum 6.0), PTE (minimum 53), Duolingo (minimum 110), or successful completion of the final level at an ELS Language Center (Level 112).
Requirements: In addition to the UMKC application, a resume, a personal statement, three letters of recommendation, official transcripts, a writing sample, and a completed English departmental application form are required.
Description: The Master of Fine Arts program at UMKC is a three-year, 45-hour course of study in creative writing and media arts. Our students focus on fiction, nonfiction, or poetry, and they take courses in a variety of other genres and media, including screenwriting, literary translation, playwriting, performance, and cross-genre work. Students also learn the theory and practice of teaching creative writing. Classes are small, supportive, and challenging. Students receive personal attention from faculty who are practicing, publishing writers and artists. Students also gain valuable experience working on one of our three national literary journals: New Letters, BkMk Press, and Number One. The UMKC MFA program is also home to the student-run journal, Newěr.
ScholarshipAmount: Graduate Teaching Assistantships include a stipend of $15,000 for the academic year. Other named scholarships and awards typically range from $250 to $1,000.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Criminal Justice and Criminology
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. The tests most commonly submitted are the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS) and Duolingo. We also accept Pearson Test of English (PTE) academic scores and have an agreement with several English Language Services (ELS) centers. Minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT 79, TOEFL pBT 550, IELTS 6.0, Duolingo 110, PTE 53, or ELS Level 112.
Requirements: Completed online application. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university. A minimum grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for the baccalaureate degree. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended. Two letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with your academic and/or professional abilities. A personal statement (500-750 words) that describes your academic and professional accomplishments, reasons for pursuing a graduate degree in criminology and criminal justice and your career goals.
Description: The Master of Science in Criminal Justice and Criminology provides a broad-based graduate-level examination of crime and the criminal justice system. The program is specifically designed to prepare students for careers in criminal and juvenile justice agencies and for further academic study. Students develop in-depth knowledge of criminological theory, research methods and statistics, criminal justice policy, and program evaluation. All students take an 18-hour required core curriculum and then tailor their degree by choosing 15 hours of electives based on their specific interests and career goals. The M.S. program also provides the option of completing a thesis.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Entrepreneurial Real Estate
EnglishScore: Official TOEFL or IELTS scores (must be less than two years old).
Department: Henry W. Bloch School of Management
Description: The Master of Science in Entrepreneurial Real Estate (M.S.E.R.E.) degree at the Bloch School of Management is Kansas City’s only master’s degree focused on real estate. At Bloch, we believe in an entrepreneurial mindset, no matter what industry you are in. Our M.S.E.R.E. is focused on entrepreneurial thinking for the real estate industry. We believe in getting out of the classroom, and our program gives you hands-on experience through project-based learning and case competitions. In the M.S.E.R.E. program, you will gain the skills to build a rewarding career in real estate. The program emphasizes an entrepreneurial approach to property, with an applied, hands-on focus.
Accredidation: The Bloch School is accredited by AACSB International, the premier accrediting body for business schools.
ScholarshipAmount: up to $2,000

ProgramName: Master of Science in Environmental and Urban Geosciences
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. UMKC will accept any one of the following as proof of English proficiency: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) iBT - Minimum score 79; International English Language Testing System (IELTS) - Minimum overall band score 6.0; Pearson Test of English (PTE) - Minimum score of 53; Duolingo English Test - Minimum score of 110; Completion of English Language Services (ELS) Level 112.
Concentration: ['Urban Environmental Geosciences', 'Urban GIS and Remote Sensing']
Description: The master of science in environmental and urban geosciences program provides an opportunity for students to improve their understanding of geosciences and to apply this knowledge to environmental and urban problems. Students will develop skills in the acquisition, analysis and presentation of geosciences data. This will provide them with a strong basis for professional careers in the geosciences or for continuing graduate study at the doctoral level.
ScholarshipAmount: The minimum stipend for a .50 FTE (20 hours per week) assistantship is $15,000 for a nine-month appointment.
ScholarshipPercentage: The UMKC Graduate Scholars award reduces the amount paid for out-of-state tuition by approximately 75 percent.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Finance
EnglishScore: For international applicants, a TOEFL or IELTS score may be required.
Requirements:
Completed online application
Official transcripts from all attended institutions sent to the UMKC Admissions Office
Official GMAT or GRE score report (waiver options available)
A 500-word statement of purpose
Current resume
International applicants have additional requirements.
Department: Henry W. Bloch School of Management
Fees: Approximately $22,000 for Missouri residents and $40,000 for non-residents (total program cost)
Description: The Master of Science in Finance (MSF) at the Bloch School of Management provides students with the advanced skills necessary to succeed in the rapidly changing, highly competitive world of finance. The program curriculum balances theory with application and emphasizes contemporary issues in the business world. Graduates will possess an understanding of modern finance theory, along with the quantitative and analytical skills to apply this theory in real-world scenarios. Our finance faculty are experts in their field, and many have direct experience as finance practitioners. The MSF program is STEM-designated and provides international students with the ability to obtain a 24-month STEM extension to their optional practical training (OPT). Our graduates have gone on to build successful careers at such companies as American Century, Cerner, Commerce Bank, the Federal Reserve Bank, State Street, and Waddell and Reed.
Accredidation: Bloch is dually accredited by AACSB International in business and accounting, an honor held by only 1% of business schools worldwide.
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $681.40, Metro Rate: $894.30, Non-Resident: $1,240.20 (for 2024-2025 academic year)
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $2,000 (Bloch Launchpad grants)

ProgramName: Master of Science in Statistics
EnglishScore: All applicants to UMKC whose native language is not English must demonstrate English language proficiency. Minimum test scores for full admission include: TOEFL 79 (iBT), IELTS 6.0, PTE 53, or Duolingo 110.
Requirements: In addition to the general requirements for admission to graduate study in the College of Arts and Sciences, the minimum requirements for admission to the master's program in statistics are: A bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. An undergraduate GPA of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Undergraduate coursework must include three semesters of calculus (through multivariate calculus) and a course in linear algebra. Students with minor deficiencies in their mathematics background may be admitted on a conditional basis. Application requirements: Unofficial transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended. A one-page statement of purpose describing the applicant's background and interest in statistics. Two letters of recommendation.
Description: The Master of Science in Statistics program is designed to provide students with a balance of statistical theory and application. Students are trained to use appropriate statistical methods to solve real-world problems. The degree is targeted towards students with strong backgrounds in quantitative areas such as mathematics, engineering and computer science. Upon graduation, our graduates go to work for industry and government, or continue to pursue doctoral studies in statistics and other related fields.
ScholarshipAmount: Valued at more than $14,000 per year (for the Chancellor's Non-Resident Award)
ScholarshipPercentage: Reduces the non-resident portion of tuition and fees by 90% (for the Chancellor's Non-Resident Award)

ProgramName: Master of Music in Woodwinds Performance
EnglishScore: Applicants who are not native speakers of English must demonstrate English proficiency before they can be admitted. UMKC accepts official results from any of the following examinations: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Pearson Test of English (PTE), Duolingo English Test (DET), or Cambridge C1 Advanced. Graduate applicants must meet the following minimum scores: TOEFL iBT: 79; TOEFL PBT: 550; IELTS: 6.0; PTE: 53; Duolingo: 110.
Requirements: Admission to the Master of Music program is based on an earned baccalaureate degree (or its equivalent) from an accredited institution, a cumulative grade-point average of 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale) in all college-level work, a successful audition in the principal performing area, and approval of the appropriate faculty and the Conservatory Graduate Committee. All applicants to graduate degree programs must also meet the general admission requirements of the UMKC School of Graduate Studies.
Description: The Master of Music in Performance is an intensive two-year course of study which prepares students for careers as professional performers and for doctoral study. Primary instruction is offered in small group settings (typically 2-4 students) or, in the case of piano and orchestral instruments, through individual lessons. Students have a wide variety of large and small ensemble opportunities available to them and are required to present two degree recitals.
Accredidation: The UMKC Conservatory is a founding member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM), and the programs in music are accredited by that body.

ProgramName: Interdisciplinary Ph.D.
EnglishScore: All applicants to the School of Graduate Studies whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following: a TOEFL score of 79 (iBT) or 550 (PBT), IELTS score of 6.0, PTE score of 53, Duolingo score of 110, or ELS Level 112 completion.
Requirements:
A master's degree or equivalent from a college or university accredited by a regional accrediting association. Applicants without a master's degree but who have completed a bachelor's degree will be considered for provisional admission. These applicants must complete 30 hours of graduate-level course work with a GPA of 3.5 or higher before they can be fully admitted to the I-Ph.D. program.
A minimum graduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended.
Three letters of recommendation addressing the applicant's academic qualifications and potential for success in doctoral study.
A personal statement (statement of purpose) of approximately 500 words describing your educational and professional background, and your goals for the Interdisciplinary Ph.D. Program.
A current resume or curriculum vitae.
A Plan of Study Form (DOC) signed by your proposed primary and co-discipline doctoral faculty advisors. It is the responsibility of the applicant to obtain these signatures.
A research plan summary of approximately 500 words describing the interdisciplinary nature of your dissertation topic.
A writing sample of at least five pages (e.g., a term paper or publication).
An official report of the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test scores, taken within the last five years, sent directly to UMKC from the Educational Testing Service. The UMKC institution code is 6872.
Description: The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program provides a path for students with unique research interests that cross traditional disciplinary boundaries. Students work with faculty from two or more different disciplines to create a doctoral program of study tailored to their specific academic and career goals. Students choose one discipline to be their coordinating discipline and at least one other to be their co-discipline.

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D.
EnglishScore: International applicants who are not native English speakers must provide proof of English proficiency. Acceptable tests and minimum scores are: TOEFL iBT 79, TOEFL PBT 550, IELTS 6.0, PTE 53, or Duolingo 105.
Description: The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program with a primary discipline in Natural Sciences provides an academic avenue for students interested in combining traditional doctoral study in one of the Natural Sciences with the opportunity to pursue an individual interest in a secondary field of study. Natural Sciences is a discipline in the College of Arts and Sciences. The primary disciplines are: Chemistry, Geosciences, Mathematics and Statistics, and Physics and Astronomy. The co-disciplines can be from a wide range of academic areas, as well as several pre-approved co-disciplines. The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program is governed by the Interdisciplinary Ph.D. Council.
ScholarshipAmount: Stipends up to $25,000 per year, plus tuition support.

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Biomedical and Health Informatics
EnglishScore: UMKC requires a minimum score on one of the following exams for graduate admission: a score of 79 on the TOEFL iBT (or 550 on the paper-based test), a 6.0 on the IELTS, a 53 on the PTE, a 110 on Duolingo, or successful completion of the ELS Level 112.
Requirements:
In addition to meeting the minimum admission requirements for the I-Ph.D. program, applicants to the bioinformatics discipline should meet the following requirements:
- Hold a master's or bachelor's degree in a discipline related to the area of study.
- An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher.
- TOEFL score of 80 or higher (for international students).
- Three letters of recommendation.
- GRE not required.
- Official transcripts.
- Statement of purpose describing research interests and educational objectives.
Description: The School of Graduate Studies offers an interdisciplinary Doctor of Philosophy degree in natural sciences. The Ph.D. program in natural sciences is for those who wish to work at the cutting edge of scientific disciplines. You will experience an individualized, research-based program that can lead to careers in biomedical research, health care technology, pharmaceutical development and research, academic research and teaching, and more. This program is a collaboration among the School of Science and Engineering, the School of Medicine, the School of Pharmacy and the School of Nursing and Health Studies. It gives you direct access to research opportunities with nationally and internationally recognized researchers. The Ph.D. in natural sciences is designed to provide you with a flexible, interdisciplinary learning and research experience. An important program element is a student-faculty advisory committee that works with you to design a plan of study and research that is centered on your needs and interests. This will ensure the greatest success for you while fulfilling the Ph.D. requirements.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $25,000 stipend plus tuition and fees (Chancellor's Doctoral Fellowship); $5,000 award (UMKC Trustees' Doctoral Fellowship)

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Cell Biology and Biophysics
EnglishScore: For international applicants: Official TOEFL, IELTS, PTE, or Duolingo scores.
Description: The graduate program in Cell Biology and Biophysics is an interdisciplinary program designed to train students for a career in academic research or in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. Students gain an in-depth understanding of the biological and biophysical sciences through a core curriculum of didactic course work combined with a selection of elective courses tailored to their specific interests. The main emphasis of the program is hands-on laboratory research, culminating in a Ph.D. dissertation. The research environment at UMKC is particularly strong in the areas of structural biology and molecular biophysics; cell, molecular and developmental biology; and the molecular basis of human disease. Many of our faculty also participate in graduate programs in the School of Biological and Chemical Sciences and the School of Pharmacy and their research laboratories are housed within the new Health Sciences Building.
ScholarshipAmount: $28,000 stipend per year

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Chemistry
EnglishScore: International students must satisfy the English language requirement of the university (TOEFL score of 550 PBT or 79 IBT; or IELTS score of 6.0).
Description: The Ph.D. degree in natural sciences with an emphasis in chemistry is for students interested in a research-intensive program. This program of study is offered through the School of Science and Engineering. Students who are accepted into the chemistry Ph.D. program are funded by research or teaching assistantships. The program includes both coursework and independent research leading to a dissertation. Students will take courses in the four major areas of chemistry — analytical, inorganic, organic and physical. Research areas are varied and include bioanalytical chemistry, drug design and discovery, green chemistry, main group chemistry, materials chemistry, medicinal chemistry, natural product chemistry, organometallic chemistry, photochemistry, physical inorganic chemistry, physical organic chemistry, polymer chemistry and supramolecular chemistry.
ScholarshipAmount: competitive stipend of $26,000 per year

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Geosciences
EnglishScore: All applicants to UMKC whose native language is not English and who do not have a bachelor's or higher degree from a U.S. accredited institution must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted scores are: TOEFL iBT 79, TOEFL PBT 550, IELTS 6.0, PTE 53, or Duolingo English Test 110. Successful completion of Level 112 at an ELS Language Center also meets the requirement.
Requirements: Students with M.S. degrees in geology, environmental science or related fields are invited to apply to the Geosciences Ph.D. discipline. Students holding B.S. degrees in these fields are normally expected to complete the M.S. in Geosciences before being considered for admission into the Ph.D. program, but outstanding students may be directly admitted into the Ph.D. program. Applications for admission should be directed to the UMKC Office of Admissions. It is strongly advised that you contact potential faculty advisors before and during the application process. The application requires a statement of purpose, curriculum vitae (CV), and three letters of recommendation.
Description: The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. provides for areas of study that are not available in existing UMKC doctoral programs. The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. is intended to serve the needs of a select group of students whose research interests may best be pursued by drawing on the academic resources of two or more disciplines. The primary discipline of Geosciences allows for students to focus their studies in areas of geology, physical geography, environmental science or urban environmental geosciences, with the specific course of study designed in conjunction with the faculty supervisory committee. A student in the Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program must meet the requirements of the School of Graduate Studies and to the university Interdisciplinary Ph.D. Program.
ScholarshipAmount: $25,000 stipend (Chancellor's Doctoral Fellowship); $5,000 (UMKC Trustees' Doctoral Fellowship)

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Mathematics
EnglishScore: Official proof of English proficiency (for non-native speakers)
Requirements: Applicants to the Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program with a primary discipline in mathematics must have a Master's degree in Mathematics, Statistics, or a closely related field. Exceptional students with a Bachelor's degree and a strong mathematics background may also be considered for admission. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 is required.
Description:
The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program provides for the study in an area that crosses two or more disciplines. Areas of emphasis under the Natural Sciences are: Chemistry, Geosciences, Mathematics, Physics, and Statistics. The School of Graduate Studies provides general administration and oversight for all Interdisciplinary Ph.D. programs. Day-to-day administration is conducted within the academic units.

The mathematics discipline offers study in several areas of mathematics. Research interests of the faculty are in the areas of analysis, complex analysis, commutative algebra, differential equations, geometry, numerical analysis, and topology.
ScholarshipAmount: The Chancellor's Doctoral Fellowship provides a $25,000 annual stipend plus tuition and fees coverage.

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry
EnglishScore: International applicants must meet the English proficiency requirements of the UMKC School of Graduate Studies. The minimum TOEFL score is 80 (internet-based) or 550 (paper-based). The minimum IELTS score is an overall band of 6.0. The minimum PTE Academic score is 53. The minimum Duolingo English Test score is 105.
Requirements: An applicant must meet the general admission requirements of the School of Graduate Studies. Additional requirements for admission to the I.Ph.D. program with a primary discipline in Molecular Biology and Biochemistry are: 1. A bachelors degree in a physical or biological science from an accredited institution. 2. An undergraduate grade-point average of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale. 3. A combined verbal and quantitative score of 300 on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is recommended, but not required for admission. 4. Three letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with the applicant’s academic qualifications and potential for advanced study and research. 5. For applicants whose native language is not English, a minimum score of 80 on the internet-based TOEFL or 6.5 on the IELTS. 6. A one-page statement describing the applicant’s interests and goals. 7. A list of all institutions of higher education attended. An application will not be considered complete until the application fee and all required materials have been received.
Department: School of Graduate Studies, School of Science and Engineering
Description: This program offers Ph.D. training in a diverse range of areas within molecular biology and biochemistry. Faculty research is centered in three general areas: gene expression, protein structure and function, and cell signaling. This core training is designed to foster analytical and creative skills so that graduates will be able to pursue independent research in an academic, industrial or government setting. Areas of specific research strengths include molecular genetics and cell biology of plants and microbes, chromatin and epigenetics, RNA biology, neurobiology, innate immunity and inflammation, biomolecular NMR, X-ray crystallography and protein biochemistry.

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Oral and Craniofacial Sciences
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. UMKC requires a minimum TOEFL score of 80 (Internet-based), an IELTS score of 6.0, a PTE score of 53 or a Duolingo score of 105.
Description: The Oral and Craniofacial Sciences area of emphasis is a research and training program leading to a Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) degree in the life sciences. The primary objective of the program is to train individuals to become leading academic researchers in the broad area of oral and craniofacial sciences. The specific areas of research emphasis within the graduate program reflect the research interests of the graduate faculty and include: Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering; Mineralized Tissue Biology; and Clinical and Translational Research. Our program offers students a unique and multidisciplinary educational experience.

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Pharmaceutical Science
EnglishScore: Applicants who are not native speakers of English must demonstrate English proficiency. UMKC requires a minimum TOEFL score of 79 (internet-based), IELTS score of 6.0, PTE score of 53 or Duolingo score of 110.
Description: The Interdisciplinary Ph.D. degree at UMKC is structured to allow students to create an individualized academic plan with a primary discipline and a co-discipline. Students can earn a Natural Sciences Ph.D. degree with an Area of Emphasis in Pharmaceutical Science through the UMKC School of Pharmacy. This is one of a few Interdisciplinary Ph.D. disciplines that does not require a co-discipline.
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $520.40 per credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,223.10 per credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: $28,000 per year

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Pharmacology
EnglishScore: For international students, a TOEFL score of at least 80 (iBT) or IELTS score of at least 6.0 is required.
Requirements:
Applicants must have a bachelor's degree from a college or university accredited by a U.S. Department of Education-recognized institutional accrediting agency, or a foreign equivalent. A minimum grade-point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for both the cumulative GPA and in the major for the bachelor's degree is required for admission. Applicants with master's degrees must have a minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.

Application Materials:
- Completed online application
- Official transcripts from all post-secondary schools attended
- A non-refundable application fee

- A resume or curriculum vitae (CV)
- A personal statement

Discipline-specific Admission Requirements:
Applicants for the Pharmacology and Toxicology track are required to have taken the Graduate Record Examination (GRE). No specific minimum score is required, but the applicant’s entire record will be considered upon formal application.
Description: The Pharmacology Ph.D. track emphasizes broad training in pharmacology and related sciences. It seeks to train scientists for academic careers in teaching and research, and for research positions in industry and government. Research opportunities encompass a variety of areas of molecular and classical pharmacology and toxicology.
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $522.90/credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,268.50/credit hour (2024-2025 rates)

ProgramName: Natural Sciences Ph.D., Area of Emphasis in Physics
EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following exams: Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), Pearson Test of English (PTE) or Duolingo English Test.
Requirements: Applicants must meet the general admission requirements of the School of Graduate Studies, as well as the discipline-specific admission requirements for both the primary and co-discipline selected. For the Physics discipline, this includes a Bachelor’s degree in physics or related field with physics background equivalent to a minor in physics, and a GPA of 3.0 or higher. For the Interdisciplinary Ph.D. program, a master's degree or its equivalent from an accredited college or university is required. The following documents must be submitted as part of your online application: two letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose, and a resume or curriculum vitae. The GRE general test is no longer required for admission to the physics discipline.
Description: The Natural Sciences Ph.D. program is designed for students seeking to contribute to research in biology, chemistry, geosciences, and physics. This program, a joint venture between the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Science and Engineering, allows students to engage with renowned faculty and state-of-the-art facilities. Graduates are equipped for advanced careers in academia, industry, and government, where they can apply their expertise to solve complex scientific problems. The curriculum emphasizes rigorous research, interdisciplinary collaboration, and the development of critical thinking and analytical skills, preparing students to become leaders and innovators in their chosen fields.
AverageScholarshipAmount: about $20,000 stipend for the nine-month academic year
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $577.80/credit hour; Midwest Student Exchange: $866.70/credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,262.20/credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: about $20,000 stipend for the nine-month academic year
ScholarshipPercentage: Full waiver of tuition and fees

ProgramName: Bachelor of Business Administration in Accounting
EnglishScore: True
Requirements: All undergraduate students entering the Bloch School B.B.A. program must meet the general University of Missouri-Kansas City admission requirements for freshmen or for transfer students.
Department: Henry W. Bloch School of Management
Description: The Bloch School's Bachelor of Business Administration (B.B.A.) is designed to provide students with a broad knowledge of business administration and opportunities for specialization in a major field of study. The curriculum ensures that students acquire the core knowledge and skills in areas such as accounting, finance, marketing, management, and information technology crucial for success in today's dynamic business environment. The program emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, communication, and ethical decision-making, preparing graduates for diverse career paths in both the private and public sectors, or for further graduate studies.
Accredidation: The Bloch School is among the 2% of business schools worldwide to be dually accredited by AACSB International in both business and accounting.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $5,000 per year

ProgramName: Minor in Actuarial Science
EnglishScore: False
Description: This minor is designed for students interested in a career as an actuary in the insurance, consulting or financial services industry. The actuarial science program provides students with skills in mathematics, statistics, computer science, and business with an emphasis on the application of these skills to financial risk management. Students are prepared to take the actuarial examinations administered by the Society of Actuaries (SOA) and the Casualty Actuarial Society (CAS).

ProgramName: Minor in Anthropology
Requirements: The minor in Anthropology requires a total of 18 credit hours of Anthropology courses with a grade of C- or better. All 18 hours must be UMKC courses. At least nine of the 18 credit hours must be at the 300- or 400-level.
Description: Anthropology is the study of humans in all their biological and cultural diversity, throughout their history and around the world. As a discipline, it combines a humanistic perspective with scientific methodologies and aims to produce knowledge that is both cross-cultural and comparative. The Minor in Anthropology is a stand-alone, flexible program for students interested in learning more about the discipline and its various subfields. It is designed to expose students to the full breadth of the discipline through courses in cultural anthropology, archaeology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. It offers students the opportunity to learn about these subfields through elective courses of their own choosing, and to develop the cross-cultural understanding and critical thinking skills that are so highly valued by employers and graduate programs today. The minor consists of 18 credit hours, nine of which must be at the 300-level or above. Students must maintain a minimum 2.0 GPA in their anthropology minor courses, and a grade of C- or better is required for all courses counting toward the minor.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $8,000 per year

ProgramName: Bachelor of Applied Science
EnglishScore: True
Requirements: Admission to the Bachelor of Applied Science (B.A.S.) degree program requires students to have earned an Associate of Applied Science (A.A.S.) degree from a regionally-accredited institution with a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher.
Department: School of Humanities and Social Sciences
Fees: Estimated annual tuition for 30 credit hours: $12,594 (Missouri Resident) / $31,794 (Non-Missouri Resident)
Description: The Bachelor of Applied Science (B.A.S.) is an undergraduate degree designed for individuals who have completed an Associate of Applied Science (A.A.S.) degree and wish to pursue a bachelor’s degree. The B.A.S. takes advantage of students’ prior technical training and occupational experience while adding professional courses, general education courses and elective courses to complete the bachelor’s degree. Students are able to apply up to 50 technical credit hours toward the 120 required for graduation. The B.A.S. curriculum prepares graduates for upward mobility in high-demand technical fields such as advanced manufacturing, construction management, hospitality management, information technology, criminal justice, public safety, health care and more. The B.A.S. program is fully online, making it accessible for working adults who need flexibility.
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $419.80/credit hour; Non-Missouri Resident: $1,059.80/credit hour
CollegeApplicationFee: Estimated annual tuition for 30 credit hours: $12,594 (Missouri Resident) / $31,794 (Non-Missouri Resident)
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $6,000 per year

ProgramName: Bachelor of Architecture
EnglishScore: True
Requirements: Students must first be admitted to UMKC before being considered for admission to the B.S.A.S. program. The B.S.A.S. program has the same general admission requirements as the university. General university requirements for freshmen include an official high school transcript, official college transcript (if applicable), and an application fee. ACT or SAT test scores are optional. In addition to the university's holistic review, all applicants to the B.S.A.S. program are evaluated by a team of AUP+D faculty members. To assist the faculty review team, all B.S.A.S. applicants are required to submit an essay of 250-500 words describing their interest in the program and any relevant background experiences.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $6,000/year

ProgramName: Minor in Art History
EnglishScore: False
Description: The Art History minor at UMKC offers students a broad grounding in the history of art through a variety of different historical periods, cultures, and media. The minor is a valuable complement for students studying studio art, history, English, foreign languages, and film studies, and provides a useful foundation for students interested in careers in museums, galleries, cultural institutions, and graduate work in art history.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Art History
EnglishScore: True
Requirements:
UMKC is a test-optional university. Applicants will be reviewed for admission based on a holistic review of their high school coursework, GPA and other supporting materials.

You will be considered for admission if you have a 2.0 or higher core GPA. You must also have one of the following:

Missouri College Preparatory Curriculum (core) requirements: 4 units of English, 4 units of Math, 3 units of Science, 3 units of Social Studies, 1 unit of Fine Arts, 3 units of Electives; OR
ACT composite score of 21 or higher; OR
SAT composite score of 1060 or higher
Description: Study the history of visual arts and culture, from antiquity to the present, while earning a Bachelor of Arts in Art History. Immerse yourself in the historical development of art and architecture, from ancient cultures to the contemporary period, as well as the social and cultural contexts in which these works were created. You’ll be prepared for careers in museums, galleries, cultural institutions and historical societies or for graduate study. In the Art History program, you will develop: Visual literacy skills, research skills, analytical skills, written and verbal communication skills.
CostPerCredit: Missouri Resident: $375.20/credit hour; Metro Rate: $566.00/credit hour; Non-Resident: $960.90/credit hour
ScholarshipAmount: Automatic scholarships for incoming freshmen range from $2,000 to $4,500.

ProgramName: Minor in Astronomy
EnglishScore: False
Description: Students completing the minor in Astronomy will gain an introduction to the physical concepts that govern the universe and develop critical skills for analysis of astronomical data. Students will develop an understanding of stars, galaxies, and cosmology and explore current topics in astronomy through participation in a research experience. The minor is a logical complement to a major in Physics, but students from any discipline may benefit from the minor. The minor consists of 18 credit hours.
ScholarshipAmount: Automatic awards for freshmen range from $1,000 to $4,500 per year.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Astronomy
EnglishScore: True
Requirements: Admission requirements for the B.S. in Astronomy are the same as for admission to the College of Arts and Sciences. According to the UMKC Admissions website, to be considered for admission, you must meet one of the following criteria: 2.75 or higher core GPA OR 24 or higher ACT score OR 1160 or higher SAT score. Applicants must also complete the Missouri college preparatory curriculum.
Description: Astronomy is the scientific study of everything in the universe beyond Earth. Astronomers work to understand the life cycles of stars and galaxies, the formation of planets, the origin and future of the universe, and much more. The Bachelor of Science in Astronomy at UMKC offers students a rigorous education in the foundational sciences with a strong emphasis in physics, preparing them for graduate study or careers in astronomy and related fields. The Physics and Astronomy Department offers extensive laboratory and research opportunities including a remote observing facility in the Rocky Mountains, a campus observatory, a state-of-the-art virtual reality visualization lab, and many research collaborations with faculty and scientists in academia, industry, and government laboratories.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $10,000 per year

ProgramName: Minor in Bioethics and Medical Humanities

Civil engineers design, build, supervise, operate and maintain infrastructure projects and systems in the public and private sectors. Civil engineering is traditionally divided into several sub-disciplines including environmental engineering, geotechnical engineering, structural engineering, transportation engineering, municipal or urban engineering, water resources engineering, materials engineering, coastal engineering, surveying, and construction engineering. Civil engineers typically work in the areas of design, construction, research and teaching, or management.

The civil engineering curriculum provides students with a broad and solid foundation in the fundamental areas of civil engineering. Students learn about sustainable design, construction materials, and the use of technology and computers to solve engineering problems. In the senior year, students complete a capstone design project that integrates their knowledge from various courses. This project provides a real-world experience, preparing students for professional practice.
